cleaned fossils is called revival.

These revived creatures aren't
technically dinosaurs anymore, so
we call them <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>vivosaurs</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.

<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>

vivosaurs.

<dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>legs</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>

So...before battle, let me explain to
you about elemental <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>type</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.

Attendant
Each vivosaur has a specific <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>type</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
Knowing this type is extremely
important in battle.

Attendant
There are five different types--Fire,
Earth, Air, Water, and Neutral.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
A vivosaur's type is indicated by the
color of its LP gauge and medal.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Different types are <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>strong </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>or <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>weak
</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>against each other.

Attendant
The arrows in this diagram
show favorable or unfavorable
type relationships.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
For example, Water is strong
against Fire, but weak against
Air.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Attacking in the direction of the
arrow results in greater damage...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
And you'll receive less damage
when attacked by the enemy.

Attendant
Be sure to pay attention to the
arrows displayed on-screen that
indicate favorable positioning.

Attendant
<dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Neutral </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>vivosaurs have no
elemental affiliation.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
There are no type advantages
with Neutrals, so there are also
no arrow indicators.

with Neutral types, which makes
them safe...but kinda dull.

the relationships among all the

right away!

Tipper
It turns out that the <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>type </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>of a
vivosaur is totally important.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
<dialogue-color-code>$c1</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-green>$p</dialogue-green><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>, have you noticed in your
battles that different LP gauges
have different shapes and colors?

Tipper
And have you noticed the different
icons next to their names and
medal colors?

Tipper
These are all based on the
vivosaur's <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>type</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
There's five different types.

Tipper
The types from top to bottom are
Fire, Earth, Air, Water, and Neutral.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Every vivosaur is one of these five
types.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Got all that? Good. Now this is the
really important part--
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Different types are <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>strong </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>or <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>weak
</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>against each other!

Tipper
The direction of the arrow points
from strong to weak.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
For example, Water is good against
Fire but weak against Air.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Attacking with the direction of the
arrow means you get an advantage
over the target...and do more damage!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
It also means that you'll take
less damage when you're attacked!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Oh, I should probably point out the
weird exception to all this--
the Neutral type.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
If a vivosaur is Neutral, there won't
be an indicator arrow at all.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
In other words, it has no strengths
or weaknesses against any other
types.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Neutrals have no risk of being weak
against an enemy but also limit your
advantage against other enemies.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
It can be tough at first to remember
what types are good against what,
but you'll get it after a while.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
If it helps, I remember it like this...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Water puts out fire, so Water beats
Fire.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Fire scorches earth, so Fire beats
Earth.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Earth stays put even in severe
winds, so Earth beats Air.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Wind blows water into big waves, so
Air beats Water.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Neutral is just out of the picture,
so it's shown by the color white.

Tipper
You'll also see arrows appear when
you're lining up attacks, so you can
pay attention to those and be fine.

Tipper
So if you've got a team full of
Fire-type vivosaurs...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
you'll have an easy time against
Earth types but won't do so well
against Water types.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Sometimes the safest thing to do is
to make a team that's balanced out
with all different types.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
I guess you could also just use only
Neutral guys and ignore the problem
altogether...
Tipper
Tipper

Tipper
You should also keep types in mind
when you're moving guys between
zones.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Always try to keep a vivosaur that
gives you a type advantage in the
Attack Zone.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
I know I'm harping on this, but you'll
really notice your battles getting
easier if you master this stuff.

Tipper
Think of listening to all this advice
as another step climbed on the
stairway to being a Master Fighter!
Tipper
Tipper
Tipper

Tipper
<dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Support effects </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>are a seriously
important part of good battling.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Good support effects can possibly
DOUBLE the power of one of your
vivosaurs or negate the other guy's!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Some vivosaurs have really powerful
support effects, and some don't
have any at all. It just varies.

Tipper
Take a look at this part right here
on your vivosaur-information screen.

Tipper
Also notice the second panel of
battle information.

Tipper
These show what kind of support
effects are being applied to whom.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Remember that these numbers are
percentages (%). So 100% up means
twice the power.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
On the other hand, 100% down means
that the power is at zero.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Support effects are only activated
when a vivosaur is in the Support
Zone. Probably why they call it that.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
You're kinda missing out if you
keep sticking vivosaurs with good
support effects in the Attack Zone.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Once they're on, support effects
keep working until your vivosaurs
change position.

Tipper
Keep in mind that some “support”
effects actually work AGAINST you.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Yeah--some support effects lower
your teammates' abilities.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
It makes sense, I guess... You'd be
off YOUR game with some of the
scarier vivosaurs right behind you.

Tipper
You can put together some super-
powerful teams if you put some
thought into your support effects.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
For example, if you have a vivosaur
with brutally high Attack but low
Accuracy...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
you can put a vivosaur in a
Support Zone that boosts its
accuracy!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Yup--with the right support effects,
you suddenly have a solid attacker!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Three vivosaurs per team gives you
lots of opportunities to build on
strengths and reduce weaknesses.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Try to think about the whole team as
a single cooperative unit. It'll give
you the edge you need to win.

Tipper
Think of listening to all this advice
as another step climbed on the
stairway to being a Master Fighter!
Tipper
Tipper
Tipper

Tipper
<dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Status effects</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. This is a big one.
Like, WOW big!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
You've probably noticed skills
in the skill panel with strange
little icons, right?

Tipper
Those are <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>status-effect icons</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
We call the skills with those icons
<dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>status-effect skills</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Status effects come in a wide
variety of types.

Tipper
Notice that there are gold AND silver
icons for the same type of status
effect.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Gold indicates a more powerful effect
than silver.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Oh, and some status effects are
applied to the enemy, while some
are applied to your teammate.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Icons with red backgrounds are
effects applied to the enemy, while
blue ones go on your allies.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Let's talk about each one, starting
with effects you put on the enemy.

Tipper
I say “enemy,” but what I mean is
the vivosaur in your opponent's
Attack Zone.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Remember that the status effects
you stick on enemies only work on
vivosaurs in the Attack Zone.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>poison</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. It deals some damage
to the target at the end of its
turn.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
This is good if your plan is to slowly
wear your enemy into the ground.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>sleep</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. Sleeping targets
can't use skills or swap positions.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Just know that if you attack a
sleeping enemy, they'll wake
right up.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>scare</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. This rattles the
target so they can't use some of
their skills.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
It's a good one to use on opponents
that like to use a specific series
of attacks.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>excite</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. An excited vivosaur
can't swap positions. He's amped up
and wants to stay in the fight.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
This is good if you want to keep
an enemy vivosaur from escaping
into the EZ.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>confuse</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. It does pretty much
what you'd expect--confuse the
target vivosaur.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
You never know what a confused
vivosaur is going to do next.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>enrage</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. This one's tricky,
'cause it raises Attack but also
seriously drops Accuracy.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Honestly, I'm not crazy about this
effect, but it's fun if you like to
take chances.

Tipper
Next, I'll explain effects that
help out your allies.

Tipper
You can also throw these status
effects on your Support Zone
teammates.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>counter</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. This lets the target
do a little damage back after it
gets hit.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
It doesn't always work, but when it
does, it's all kinds of fun.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Oh, and this is the only beneficial
status effect that the vivosaur can
apply only to itself.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>enflame</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. It raises the
target's Attack.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
There's nothing fancy about
increasing Attack...but who doesn't
want to be more powerful?

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>harden</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. It raises Defense.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Simple, but pretty darn effective.

Tipper
This is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>quicken</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>. This effect makes it
easier to dodge enemy attacks.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Doesn't matter how hard the other
WOULD have hit you, am I right?

Tipper
Of course, your opponents'll use
skills with status effects too.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
So what do you do when your
vivosaurs have some horrible
status effect on them?
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
There are two options...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
The first is swapping.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
If you swap the afflicted vivosaur
out of the AZ, the status effect
goes away.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Let's say your vivosaur is <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Poisoned</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
You can even swap him out before he
gets hurt by the poison!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
The downside is that any beneficial
effects on that vivosaur will also
disappear.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
The second option is to use a skill
that removes status effects.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
There aren't a lot of them, but some
vivosaurs learn skills that can clear
all status effects from the target.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
With skills like that, you can get
out of unwanted status effects
without having to swap!

Tipper
The key to status effects is when
and where to use them.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
With good targets and timing, 
you can take better advantage of
your team's strong points.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
The best advice I can give you is to
really think about these things when
building your team.

Tipper
Whew! Another step climbed on the
stairway to Master Fighter status!
Tipper
Tipper

Tipper
<dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Team skills </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>are something that get
more and more important as you play.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
I'm sure you're finding now, since
you've fought a few battles, that
team creation is a big deal.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Team members can help each other
out in a buncha different ways...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
One way is banding together to
use team skills.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
This is an area where they're still
doing a lot of research. There's a
lot we still don't know...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
But we do know that some vivosaurs
have a certain chemistry with certain
other vivosaurs.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Basically, vivosaurs work better with
some teammates than with others.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
And if you team up three vivosaurs
with chemistry like this, you can use
some seriously powerful team skills!

Tipper
Maybe you've noticed that some
skills show up in a strange color?
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
This is a team skill.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Team skills are generally more
powerful than regular skills...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
And if you use them right, team
skills can be the difference between
winning and losing!

Tipper
You're probably wondering who you
need to team up to use team skills,
right?
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Well, that's something that you'll
have to figure out as you go. I 
can't just tell you EVERYTHING.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
But keep in mind that all three
teammates have to stay in the fight
to use a team skill.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
And remember that even if you do
discover a team skill, you still
gotta use it well to win!

Tipper
Whew! Another step climbed on
the stairway to Master Fighter
status!

Tipper
Tipper

Tipper
<dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Special skills </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>are one of the more
advanced--but powerful--things
to master about battle strategy.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
You've probably seen that some
vivosaurs have more than just normal
attacks, status effects, and such. 
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Maybe you've seen <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>transformation
</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>skills.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Transformation skills let certain
vivosaurs change themselves into
stronger vivosaurs.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
There's also <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>FP-damaging skills</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Some skills let you deal damage
directly to the enemy FP pool,
preventing them from using skills.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Another type that you'll find
a lot are <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>knock </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>skills.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
These skills knock enemy vivosaurs
out of the Attack Zone and into the
Escape Zone. 
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Take a look at skill descriptions to
identify the special skills.

Tipper
I should mention that learning how to
take advantage of special skills can
be tricky...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
but they're just the sort of thing
that separates great Fighters from
merely good Fighters.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
There are plenty of good vivosaur
combinations out there to really
take advantage of special skills.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Give 'em a try!

Tipper
So anyway, there's another step
climbed on the stairway to Master
Fighter status!

<dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Abilities </dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>can easily be the difference
between winning and losing.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
<dialogue-color-code>$c1</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-green>$p</dialogue-green><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>, you've probably seen a
bunch of these abilities in battle
already.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Abilities are special powers that
a good number of vivosaurs have.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
The useful thing about abilities is
that they're always on. You don't

<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Pay attention to vivosaur
descriptions, and you should be able

Tipper
For example, there's <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Auto LP
Recovery</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
This just means that the vivosaur
heals up a little damage to its
LP every turn.

Tipper
There's also <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Auto Counter</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
This lets a vivosaur that gets
attacked turn around and deal
a little damage back to the attacker.

Tipper
What else...? Oh yeah! <dialogue-color-code>$c2</dialogue-color-code><dialogue-red>Parting Blow</dialogue-red><dialogue-color-code>$c0</dialogue-color-code>.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Vivosaurs with this ability get a big
power boost when they're really low
on LP.

Tipper
Some people treat them like big
weapons, but vivosaurs are living,
breathing creatures!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Between the support effects...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
special skills...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
and abilities...
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
all vivosaurs are unique in their
own special way.
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
They can't be judged by words like

<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
Every vivosaur wants to battle at
its very best. Only you, the Fighter,
can help them do that!
<dialogue-color-code>$f</dialogue-color-code>
...Only YOU can let them realize their
full potential!
